title: Constraints Overview
description: A narrative guide to core table constraints in DuckDB (NOT NULL, DEFAULT, PRIMARY KEY, UNIQUE, CHECK, simulated FOREIGN KEY patterns, and safe migration techniques). Each section starts with a practical question and ends with an idempotent runnable snippet plus cross-engine notes.

sections.title: 0. Introduction: Core Constraints
sections.description: Why constraints matter: push invariants to the data layer — NOT NULL, DEFAULT, PRIMARY KEY, UNIQUE, CHECK, and simulated FOREIGN KEY patterns.
sections.narrative: Constraints capture non-negotiable data rules near the source. They reduce downstream COALESCEs and dedupe logic, surface errors earlier, and document schema intent. Even where enforcement is limited, patterns like CTAS filtering and orphan scans provide practical safeguards.
sections.nerd_notes: Think: PK = identity (unique + not null), UNIQUE = alternate key, NOT NULL = presence, DEFAULT = convenience, CHECK = domain rule, FK = relationship integrity (simulate if not enforced).

sections.title: 1. Create products table with constraints
sections.description: Establish a base table demonstrating multiple constraint types together.

examples.name: create_products
examples.description: Question: how do we define a small product table that showcases PRIMARY KEY, NOT NULL, UNIQUE, CHECK, and DEFAULT in one place?
examples.nerd_notes: Combining constraints early documents invariants. DuckDB treats constraints mostly as metadata (except NOT NULL). Use CHECK for simple domain rules; complex validation can happen in ETL staging.

compat_examples.postgres: -- Postgres: prefer NUMERIC(10,2) for currency; add GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY if auto IDs desired.
compat_examples.mysql: -- MySQL: use DECIMAL(10,2) for currency; INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY if you need auto IDs.
compat_examples.oracle: -- Oracle: use NUMBER types; add GENERATED BY DEFAULT AS IDENTITY for surrogate keys if needed.

sections.narrative: We start with a compact table so later examples can focus on isolating one constraint at a time.
sections.nerd_notes: Idempotent demo pattern (DROP + CREATE) keeps lessons repeatable; production migrations should use ALTER or copy-swap patterns.

sections.title: 1.5 Cheat Sheet: Common Patterns
sections.description: Copy-ready snippets to apply constraints and validate data quickly.

examples.name: cs_not_null_default_combo
examples.description: NOT NULL with DEFAULT for clean inserts.
examples.nerd_notes: Defaults prevent NULL floods while NOT NULL asserts presence.

examples.name: cs_unique_alt_key
examples.nerd_notes: Use UNIQUE for human identifiers; pair with NOT NULL when appropriate.

examples.name: cs_check_ctas_filter
examples.nerd_notes: Stage data, filter invalids, then adopt the clean table.

examples.name: cs_fk_orphan_scan
examples.nerd_notes: Run orphan scans on ingest to mimic FK assurance.

sections.narrative: Use these building blocks to encode common invariants quickly.
sections.nerd_notes: All snippets are idempotent; safe to re-run in CI or the playground.

sections.title: 1.6 Pitfalls, Tips, and Q&A

examples.name: pitfall_unique_and_nulls
examples.description: Q: Why are multiple NULLs allowed with UNIQUE?
examples.nerd_notes: UNIQUE treats NULL as 'unknown' so multiple NULLs are permitted in many engines. Add NOT NULL to disallow.

examples.name: tip_copy_swap_migrations
examples.description: Tip: Use copy-validate-swap for big changes.
examples.nerd_notes: Safer than in-place ALTER in analytic engines; validate counts and invariants before swapping.

examples.name: question_pk_vs_unique
examples.description: Q: When to choose PRIMARY KEY vs UNIQUE?
examples.nerd_notes: PRIMARY KEY conveys table identity and forbids NULL; UNIQUE is best for alternate identifiers and can allow NULL.

examples.name: tricky_check_aggregation
examples.nerd_notes: No; CHECK works per-row. Use ETL validations or materialized checks for cross-row constraints.

examples.name: fundamental_fk_validation_job
examples.description: Q: How to approximate FOREIGN KEY enforcement in pipelines?
examples.nerd_notes: Schedule orphan scans and fail the job when count > 0; quarantine bad rows for triage.

sections.narrative: These notes help you pick the right constraint and avoid silent data-quality issues.
sections.nerd_notes: Document constraint intent in DDL comments or adjacent docs to aid future maintainers.

sections.title: 2. Violations and enforcement
sections.description: Show what happens (conceptually) when constraint rules would be broken.

examples.name: violation_examples
examples.sql:
-- Uncomment lines to observe failures in an interactive session
-- INSERT INTO products (product_id, name) VALUES (3, NULL);          -- NOT NULL violation
-- INSERT INTO products (product_id, name, sku) VALUES (3,'DupSKU','G-200'); -- UNIQUE violation
SELECT product_id, name, sku, price, stock_quantity FROM products ORDER BY product_id;
examples.description: Question: how would NOT NULL or UNIQUE violations appear if we attempted them?
examples.nerd_notes: Keeping failing statements commented preserves validator success while documenting expected errors. Always capture the intent of failures in teaching material.

compat_examples.postgres: -- Same errors raised with detailed constraint names in messages.
compat_examples.mysql: -- MySQL emits error codes (e.g., 1062 for duplicate key).
compat_examples.oracle: -- Oracle raises ORA-00001 for unique constraint violations; ORA-01400 for NOT NULL.

sections.narrative: Surfacing violations clarifies each constraint's protective role without breaking automated validation.
sections.nerd_notes: In CI you typically run only successful scripts; keep a separate document for intentional failure repro steps.

sections.title: 3. Adding constraints later (safe patterns)
sections.description: Use a copy-swap pattern to retrofit or tighten constraints when ALTER ADD is limited.

examples.name: add_constraint
examples.description: Question: how can we safely add or tighten a constraint in DuckDB when direct ALTER ADD is limited?
examples.nerd_notes: Pattern: create copy with desired schema, populate only valid rows, swap names. Validate row counts match before dropping source. This generalizes to type changes and CHECK additions.

compat_examples.postgres: -- Could instead: ALTER TABLE products ADD COLUMN new_col ...; ALTER TABLE ... ADD CONSTRAINT ...;
compat_examples.mysql: -- ALTER TABLE supports ADD CONSTRAINT; copy-swap still useful for large reorganizations.
compat_examples.oracle: -- Use ENABLE NOVALIDATE then VALIDATE CONSTRAINT for phased rollout.

sections.narrative: Copy-swap gives transactional clarity in analytic contexts where full ALTER semantics are absent or limited.
sections.nerd_notes: Always test on a temp table first for large data sets; measure row counts + checksums to ensure fidelity.

sections.title: 4. CHECK constraints examples
sections.description: Simulate adding a CHECK by filtering invalid rows into a new table.

examples.name: check_examples
examples.description: Question: how do we enforce a new rule (discount >= 0) on existing rows without native ALTER ADD CHECK?
examples.nerd_notes: Build a filtered CTAS capturing only valid rows; store rejects separately if auditing. Works for range rules and simple relational checks.

compat_examples.postgres: -- ALTER TABLE products ADD CONSTRAINT chk_discount CHECK (discount >= 0) NOT VALID; VALIDATE CONSTRAINT chk_discount;
compat_examples.mysql: -- Modern MySQL enforces CHECK; earlier versions ignored it (pre-8.0.16).
compat_examples.oracle: -- ALTER TABLE products ADD CONSTRAINT chk_discount CHECK (discount >= 0) ENABLE NOVALIDATE.

sections.narrative: Filtered-copy approach is universal and explicit, making hidden data quality issues visible during migration.
sections.nerd_notes: For complex expressions prefer staging tables plus validation queries before adopting new constraints.

sections.title: 5. NOT NULL + DEFAULT patterns
sections.description: Demonstrate providing defaults while requiring presence for business-critical columns.

examples.name: notnull_default_demo
examples.description: Question: how do NOT NULL and DEFAULT combine to guarantee presence while reducing boilerplate in inserts?
examples.nerd_notes: Pair DEFAULT with NOT NULL to centralize implicit values. Avoid sprinkling COALESCE in downstream queries.

compat_examples.postgres: -- IDENTICAL semantics; consider GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY for profile_id.
compat_examples.mysql: -- Use AUTO_INCREMENT for surrogate key; TIMESTAMP defaults vary by sql_mode.
compat_examples.oracle: -- Use DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP; identity column for profile_id optionally.

sections.narrative: Defaults cut repetition while NOT NULL asserts intent. This pairing forms the backbone of reliable dimension tables.
sections.nerd_notes: Audit columns: if application always supplies a value, make it NOT NULL + possibly DEFAULT for convenience.

sections.title: 6. PRIMARY KEY variants
sections.description: Show column-level, table-level and composite PK definitions (simplified).

examples.name: primary_key_variants
examples.description: Question: what are the forms of declaring a PRIMARY KEY (inline, named, composite)?
examples.nerd_notes: Composite keys encode business identity; consider a surrogate key only if join fan-out or late arriving facts push complexity.

compat_examples.postgres: -- All forms identical; composite builds multicolumn btree index.
compat_examples.mysql: -- InnoDB clusters by PRIMARY KEY; choose carefully for write patterns.
compat_examples.oracle: -- Creates unique index; naming constraints helps future maintenance.

sections.narrative: Different syntaxes convey the same invariant: row identity. Named constraints aid future ALTER/DROP maintenance.
sections.nerd_notes: If future scaling needs a surrogate key, demote composite key to UNIQUE and add new PK.

sections.title: 7. Simulated FOREIGN KEY patterns
sections.description: Demonstrate maintaining parent/child relationships and detecting orphan rows without enforced FOREIGN KEY support.

examples.name: foreign_key_simulation
examples.description: Question: how can we model and validate parent→child relationships when the engine doesn't enforce FOREIGN KEY constraints?
examples.nerd_notes: Pattern: (1) maintain parent table, (2) insert child rows, (3) run LEFT JOIN anti-checks to surface orphans. Schedule integrity queries in ETL/QA pipelines. Optionally quarantine orphans before analytics.

compat_examples.postgres: -- Native: CREATE TABLE fk_items (... category_id INTEGER REFERENCES fk_categories(category_id) ON DELETE CASCADE);
compat_examples.mysql: -- Native: FOREIGN KEY (category_id) REFERENCES fk_categories(category_id) ON DELETE SET NULL; (InnoDB only)
compat_examples.oracle: -- Native: FOREIGN KEY (category_id) REFERENCES fk_categories(category_id) ON DELETE NO ACTION;

sections.narrative: We simulate referential integrity with validation queries. Orphan detection queries become part of data quality checks.
sections.nerd_notes: You can materialize a report of orphans and fail a pipeline if count > 0 to mimic enforced constraints.

sections.title: 8. UNIQUE constraints (single & composite)
sections.description: Demonstrate single-column and multi-column uniqueness plus nullable behavior.

examples.name: unique_variants
examples.description: Question: how do single-column UNIQUE constraints differ from composite UNIQUE constraints?
examples.nerd_notes: Single-column UNIQUE prevents duplicates per column; composite enforces tuple uniqueness. Multiple NULLs are typically allowed (engine-dependent).

compat_examples.postgres: -- Allows multiple NULLs; create partial unique indexes for filtered uniqueness.
compat_examples.mysql: -- Multiple NULLs allowed (InnoDB) but treat carefully with queries; consider IS NOT NULL filters.
compat_examples.oracle: -- Multiple NULLs allowed; use function-based indexes to normalize values first.

sections.narrative: Choosing between single and composite uniqueness shapes how natural keys are represented and validated.
sections.nerd_notes: Avoid over-constraining with many UNIQUE indexes—each adds write overhead.

sections.title: 9. CHECK constraint complexity
sections.description: Illustrate combining several domain checks succinctly (simplified version).

examples.name: check_complex_demo
examples.description: Question: how can multiple simple CHECK constraints create guardrails for numeric inputs?
examples.nerd_notes: Small atomic CHECK constraints are clearer than one mega-condition. They localize error sources and simplify future edits.

compat_examples.postgres: -- Combine or separate constraints; naming each aids targeted troubleshooting.
compat_examples.mysql: -- Modern MySQL enforces; legacy versions silently ignored CHECK clauses.
compat_examples.oracle: -- Consider DISABLE NOVALIDATE for phased adoption on large legacy tables.

sections.narrative: Atomic checks compose a safety net that is both readable and maintainable compared to sprawling boolean expressions.
sections.nerd_notes: Prefer multiple named checks over one aggregated predicate for clarity.

sections.title: 10. Constraint management & cleanup
sections.description: Centralized cleanup to keep re-runs idempotent.

examples.name: cleanup
examples.sql: DROP TABLE IF EXISTS products; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS products_tmp; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS customer_profiles; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS pk_single_col; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS pk_named; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS pk_composite; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS fk_items; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS fk_categories; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS unique_demo; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS unique_composite; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS order_line;
examples.description: Question: how do we drop all objects created during constraint demonstrations?
examples.nerd_notes: Cleanup ensures subsequent lessons start clean; production systems would ALTER not DROP.

compat_examples.postgres: -- Add CASCADE if dependent views exist.
compat_examples.mysql: -- DROP TABLE IF EXISTS supported; ensure transactions committed first.
compat_examples.oracle: -- Use PURGE if recycle bin side-effects undesired.

sections.narrative: Keeping educational schemas tidy avoids cross-test contamination.
sections.nerd_notes: Consider a dedicated schema per lesson in multi-user environments.

exercises.answer_sql: SELECT product_id, COUNT(*) AS cnt FROM products GROUP BY product_id ORDER BY cnt DESC;

exercises.prompt: Select the top 10 rows where `product_id` is positive (if numeric) or not null otherwise.
exercises.answer_sql: SELECT * FROM products WHERE product_id IS NOT NULL AND product_id > 0 LIMIT 10;
